Dr. Crofts: I'm Dr. Penny Crofts from the
Faculty of Law, UTS.

3.text:
David: Penny your research is a about many
things, what's it major theme?

7.text:
Dr. Crofts: I focused particularly on legal
constructions of wickedness. My central theory

13.text:
is that wickedness is not something that exists
out there, it's something that we as a society

18.text:
construct and law is one discourse among many
that tells us right from wrong, good from

25.text:
evil, and so I look at how the law constructs
wickedness.

28.text:
David: What does the poison apple have to
do with wickedness? Tell me that story.

31.text:
Dr. Crofts: There's a 16th century case called
Saunders that we still use as an authority

37.text:
in contemporary criminal law and this man
called Saunders wanted to kill his wife because,

43.text:
and it says in the case note, he had been
seduced by the devil so he'd fallen in love

49.text:
with another woman and so he got an apple,
roasted it and poisoned it and then gave it

54.text:
to his wife to kill her. She didn't know it
was poisoned and she gave it to their child

61.text:
and he said, "Are apple's good for children?"
She basically said, "Of course they are,"

67.text:
and the child ate the apple and died.
He was judged with murder and there was this

73.text:
difficulty because he said, "I didn't want
to murder my child I wanted to murder my wife,"

78.text:
and so we regard it as a really an important
case in contemporary criminal law because

83.text:
it introduced the notion of transferred malice.
If you want to kill one person and you shoot

89.text:
at them and you accidentally missed then your
malice is transferred and you can be charged

93.text:
with murder for the other person.
David: In a sense then, the actual, kind of

99.text:
what? The evil goes through the apple?
Dr. Crofts: Well, this is the interesting

102.text:
thing because one thing I noticed when I look
at treatise writers between the 16th and 18th

108.text:
century, so these were people who basically
were trying to organize and summarize the

111.text:
law. Every single treatise writer referred
to the apple and I thought this is really

117.text:
weird. It's not just about intention there's
more going on here about why Saunders was

124.text:
wicked. He was wicked in part because there
was this incredible horror at using poison

131.text:
at the time and it was also ... a really sneaky
thing to do.

136.text:
There's this whole idea that you could kill
people if you killed in an honorable way but

140.text:
it was dishonorable to be stealthy, so hiding
in the bushes, poisoning, would always be

146.text:
regarded as particularly wicked at that time.
Whereas if you come up to someone and you

152.text:
go, "I'm angry at you, you stole my sheep,"
and say you have a fight then that would be

156.text:
a fair fight and would be honorable and that
would not be regarded as being as wicked as

163.text:
killing by ambush or killing by poison.
There's one treatise writer in particular

169.text:
who just obsessed over all the different ways
you could kill someone with poison so it was

174.text:
this great fear but then on top of that the
mention of the ... They're quite obsessed

180.text:
by the apple and they don't talk about it
being a roasted apple, they only talk about

184.text:
it being an apple which I thought was quite
interesting as well. To give you some idea,

189.text:
treatise writers tended not to refer to cases
they tended to refer to each other but not

193.text:
to cases.
This is really weird that all the treatise

197.text:
writers talk about this case and almost all
of them talk about the apple and so I was

201.text:
looking at it and when you think of an apple
and you think of wickedness, you think if

205.text:
Adam and Eve. What I think treatise writers
were trying to do at this time was to construct

211.text:
a persuasive model of wickedness. This idea
that wickedness would be caught by criminal

218.text:
law.
They didn't want to settle on one definition

221.text:
of what it meant to be wicked because sometimes
if you intended to kill a person it would

225.text:
be wicked and sometimes it wouldn't and sometimes
a man poisoning they said was always wicked.

230.text:
They didn't like poisoning and causing someone's
death was bad in on of itself because you

236.text:
were taking a life from God but then in addition
you've got this apple popping up. I think

241.text:
that they were ... it was reference also to
Adam and Eve and that association of the apple

249.text:
with wickedness and this persuasion that wickedness
was something that could be moved around,

255.text:
it could be moved from person to person.
David: But today Adam and Eve, I mean, do

261.text:
we still worry about that in court? People
talking about Adam and Eve and apples?

264.text:
Dr. Crofts: Well, the way, I mean treatise
writers didn't try and disrupt the Adam and

270.text:
Eve story but they drew upon it as basically
saying this is something that criminal law

275.text:
had ... Unfortunately, there is evil in the
world and criminal law must respond to it

279.text:
because of Adam and Eve.
Whenever I tell people, modern people about

284.text:
this case and the apple they always think
of Adam and Eve but in addition they also

290.text:
think of Snow White. Snow White came after
the 16th century case but for us it's one

299.text:
of the classics as well, and what's interesting
in Adam and Eve and Snow White is that the

305.text:
women are wicked. It's the women who are the
problem.

310.text:
What's interesting about this case is almost
all the treatise writer's record that the

315.text:
wife was disobedient. That the husband had
told her, "Don't give the apple to the kid,"

322.text:
and she still did, so it's almost like it's
her fault that the child had died and they

327.text:
actually spend some time explaining why she
couldn't be found guilty even though she caused

333.text:
the death.
What I thought was really interesting is there's

336.text:
this developing fear around this time that
wickedness would escape the law. They weren't

342.text:
concerned about innocent men being found guilty
they were concerned that wickedness escaping

346.text:
the law.
You have this wife who gave the apple to the

351.text:
child unknowingly and was disobedient and
that was called petty treason if you would

355.text:
... if a wife was disobedient to her husband
that was petty treason. She was offending

360.text:
against structures at that time. It was petty
treason, if you killed them, sorry.

367.text:
Disobedience wasn't petty treason but there
were these structures of obedience but you

370.text:
also had the woman, the other woman. We have
no idea if she loved Saunders or if she had

378.text:
encouraged this or if it was a completely
unrequited passion but in the case note she's

383.text:
described as a devil but neither her nor the
wife are charged with criminal offenses.

391.text:
You've got this underlying message about women
in particular escaping criminal responsibility

401.text:
and in contemporary criminal law we talked
about that as the dark figure of crime.

406.text:
David: So, we've got crime as evil kind of
being passed via objects, apples and that

413.text:
kind of stuff and then somehow it becomes
the woman's problem?

419.text:
Dr. Crofts: I think that that really ... the
apple's quite interesting because it's quite

423.text:
free floating like it moves from one person
to another but then in addition you've got

428.text:
this question if of who should be regarded
wicked? Who should be regarded as responsible?

436.text:
It's a big question what does it mean to be
wicked? And we still don't answer that.

441.text:
David: Even after all this time?
Dr. Crofts: I actually think we've got worst

444.text:
rather than better. I think in contemporary
criminal law the dominant account of wickedness

450.text:
is intentional wrongdoing and this reflects
-

454.text:
David: But what does that mean?
Dr. Crofts: It means that you want to ... I

459.text:
focus on murder, so I'll keep talking about
it on murder but it means that you want, you

463.text:
intend to kill someone or you recognize the
risk that you're going to kill someone. It's

468.text:
a cognitive account of wickedness and it reflects
our understandings of wickedness in everyday

475.text:
life as well.
If someone ... if you're meeting someone at

479.text:
a restaurant and they don't turn up and then
you ring them and go, "Where are you?" They

484.text:
say, "Oh, I'm so sorry I forgot." You'll excuse
them whereas if you ring them and go, "Where

489.text:
are you?" And they go, "Haha! I wanted to
keep you waiting. That was my plan." You would

494.text:
think that they weren't very nice and that
they were ... that this was a bad thing, so

499.text:
we tend to focus on intention in contemporary
criminal law.

504.text:
You actually have cases saying people weren't
to be found guilty unless they have mens rea.

509.text:
Sometimes that is really important, sometimes
that intention is really important but the

513.text:
problem is this is a really thin account of
wickedness in contemporary criminal law.

518.text:
We find it really difficult to explain, for
example, what if that person always stands

522.text:
you up and they always forget you? You would
start to be a bit cranky at them so the issue

529.text:
there is that we're not capturing all the
ways in which you can be bad in criminal law.

536.text:
We're also not reflecting all the things ... all
the ways in which criminal law constructs

541.text:
wickedness.
Yes, there's this focus on intention but for

545.text:
example, in compulsion defenses like self-defense,
duress, and necessity where you basically

550.text:
said, "I was forced to do this." What you're
basically saying is, "Yes, I intended to kill

555.text:
the person but I didn't want to." That's an
emotional account of wickedness.

562.text:
You also have all these other offenses which
are the ones that most affects us in daily

568.text:
life like strict liability offenses like speeding.
It doesn't matter if you know whether you're

572.text:
speeding or not what matters is that you were
speeding. So, if an officer pulls you aside

577.text:
and you go, "Oh, I'm really sorry I had no
idea," you're still guilty, really criminal

581.text:
law is all about whether someone is bad enough
to justify punishment and the problem is that

590.text:
we avoid that discussion of what it means
to be wicked.

595.text:
What originally got me interested in this
research was the case of Lavender.

599.text:
David: Tell me that Lavender.
Dr. Crofts: Lavender was this case where this

603.text:
guy was working at a sand mine and some kids
came, four kids came on to the property and

610.text:
he was driving a front hand loader with limited
visibility. He went very slowly and he decided

617.text:
that he would drive the front end loader at
the kids to frighten them off the land mine

623.text:
but it's not the land mine, the mine. That
they shouldn't be there so he would drive

627.text:
the front end loader at them to frighten them
away.

630.text:
So, he drove the front end loader at them
and two of the kids, he could see two of the

634.text:
kids in the distance but the other two kids
hid behind some shruberry and unfortunately

641.text:
he drove over the bushes and killed one of
the children. He was charged with manslaughter

648.text:
by criminal negligence.
There was this big discussion and because

652.text:
the central element of manslaughter by criminal
negligence is that you have to be wickedly

657.text:
negligent or you can talk about it as being
grossly negligent, criminally negligent but

662.text:
ultimately its wickedness.
It went to the news of what's called Court

668.text:
of Criminal Appeal and what I thought was
particularly fascinating because criminal

673.text:
law has been talking about good and bad, mostly
bad, for centuries, but the guys at the Criminal

680.text:
Court of Appeal, and they were three different
judges who had three different arguments about

686.text:
what it meant to be wicked.
One of them basically said, "Wickedness is

691.text:
whatever the law says wickedness is. It doesn't
really matter." It's almost like a semantic

697.text:
game and this ... I found this quite a concerning
model of law because it basically removes

705.text:
values and norms, lowers this closed system
and values are whatever the laws says the

713.text:
values are. This judge actually thought wickedness
should probably be removed as an epithet from

721.text:
criminal law.
The second judge said, "No, no, no, you're

725.text:
wrong wickedness is integral to criminal law
but you can only be wicked if you have intentional

733.text:
knowledge." This is a classic subjective model
of wickedness. He thought that Lavender should

739.text:
not be found guilty because he didn't have
intentional knowledge.

744.text:
Then the third judge said, "No, no, no, there
are different accounts of wickedness. One

750.text:
account of wickedness is intentional wrongdoing
but another account of wickedness is an absence

756.text:
of care, a lack of care and that's what we
associate with negligence that you fail to

761.text:
care."
What I really love about this model of wickedness

765.text:
is that it returned us to classic account
if wickedness, like an Aristotle in account

770.text:
of wickedness, where you don't assume intentional
knowledge. What you're looking at is almost

778.text:
a balance on whether you have excess or lack
and so what you're focus ... an example of

787.text:
someone who would be regarded as wicked who
didn't necessarily have intention if you believe

792.text:
it would be Eichmann who sent Jews to their
death on trains. He said, "I ... I didn't

799.text:
really want to kill any Jews I just wanted
to be really good at my job." Being ... wanting

804.text:
to be really at your job isn't only a positive
thing but in this situation it's this absence

810.text:
of balance, it's this excessive ambition and
the failure to care for human life and that

816.text:
what makes Eichmann wicked.
It's the same with Lavender that he wanted

822.text:
to frighten them off the property but he failed
to exercise care. He failed to worry about

831.text:
human life in that situation so that we as
a society would say, "Well, that's wicked

837.text:
in that situation."
Then he went on appeal to the High Court.

842.text:
The High Court on the transcript were like,
"Wickedness. How fascinating," and then they

848.text:
just left that question to the side they didn't
really deal with it.

852.text:
So, why my research is important because we
have a judiciary and legal theorists who don't

862.text:
really talk about a central project of criminal
law which is wickedness. We have cases like

869.text:
Lavender where they can't articulate why Lavender
should or should not be found guilty. They

876.text:
ended up finding him guilty but they couldn't
express it so what I'm trying to do us provide

882.text:
a philosophical account of what kinds of models
of wickedness are available and what are the

890.text:
cause and benefits of particular models of
wickedness.

893.text:
David: Which is your favorite then?
Dr. Crofts: Well, I think that there's lots

897.text:
of different types. The intentional wrongdoing,
I think, is important but I'm trying to address

903.text:
the lack of focus on that sort of death, classic
account of wickedness of an absence of goodness,

910.text:
the lack of care. It's a beautiful model of
wickedness and I think it's a really important

916.text:
model of wickedness in contemporary life where
people have failed to worry about other people,

924.text:
to think about other people, to care for other
people.
